content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Leah Robinson: I was born and raised in the United States, in a small town in the West South Central region, and I've always felt a deep connection to my roots. My parents both have graduate degrees, which was pretty rare in our community back then, and they always emphasized the importance of education. I grew up in a tight-knit family, living with both of my parents, and we had a stable household with above-average income. My father was a professor at a local university, and my mother worked as a nurse, so I was exposed to both academia and healthcare from a young age. I remember sitting in on my father's lectures when I was a kid, and that sparked my love for learning. I was always curious, always asking questions, and I think that's what led me to pursue a graduate degree in social work. I wanted to help people in the way my mother did, but also to address the systemic issues that my father often talked about. I moved to Dallas when I was 18 for college, and I've been here ever since, though I've changed cities a few times. I've never been married, and I've always focused on my career and my community. I work full-time now as a social worker, and I'm still very active in my church, which has been a big part of my life since I was a teenager. I'm proud of where I came from, and I'm grateful for the opportunities I've had.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Leah Robinson: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads moment for me, and it came right after I finished my undergraduate degree. I had been accepted into a prestigious graduate program in public policy, which was a huge opportunity. At the same time, I was offered a full-time position at a nonprofit organization focused on community outreach and mental health support. I was torn because the graduate program would have given me a broader platform to effect change on a systemic level, but the nonprofit job would have allowed me to work directly with people in need, face-to-face, in the communities I grew up in. I spent weeks talking to my parents, my pastor, and even some of my professors. My father reminded me that while policy can shape the world, it's the people on the ground who make those policies meaningful. My mother, on the other hand, encouraged me to pursue the degree because she believed it would give me more tools to help others in the long run. In the end, I chose the nonprofit job. It was a hard decision, but I knew I wanted to be where the impact was immediate and tangible. That choice shaped my career path, and it's what led me to social work. Looking back, I don't regret it. I've been able to build deep relationships with the people I serve, and I feel like I'm making a real difference in their lives every day.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Leah Robinson: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable. I had spent so much time thinking about what kind of impact I wanted to have, and I kept coming back to the idea that I wanted to be in the room with the people I was trying to help. It wasn't just about making a decision—it was about aligning my values with my actions. I remember sitting on my porch one evening, staring at the stars, and just knowing that I couldn't walk away from the people who needed me right then. I didn't want to be someone who changed the world from a distance. I wanted to be someone who changed lives, one person at a time. That moment, that clarity, felt like a gift. It made the choice feel less like a sacrifice and more like a calling.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Leah Robinson: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk through those decisions with was really important. My pastor was a huge support during that time—he helped me see that my purpose wasn't just about the path I took, but about the heart behind it. He reminded me that God doesn't always give us the easiest road, but He gives us the strength to walk it. My parents were also there, offering their wisdom without pushing me in any particular direction. I also reached out to a few mentors from my undergraduate days, people who had made similar choices in their careers. They shared their own stories, which helped me realize that there was no one-size-fits-all answer. In the end, it was a combination of support systems—family, faith, and professional guidance—that helped me make the decision that felt right for me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Leah Robinson: I don't have a partner or children at the moment, but my family remains a central part of my life. My parents are still very much involved in my journey, and we talk often—whether it's about work, faith, or just catching up. My father still teaches part-time, and my mother continues her work in healthcare, though she's now in a supervisory role. I also have a younger sister who's a teacher in the same town where I grew up, and we keep in close contact. While I've never married, I've always felt like I have a strong support system in my family and my church community. I think having that foundation has given me the confidence to pursue my work in social services without feeling like I'm missing out on something. I'm content with where I am, and I believe that my family's love and encouragement have been instrumental in shaping who I am today.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my journey has been shaped by the values I was raised with, the people who supported me, and the choices I made when faced with crossroads. Reflecting on my life story, I see how my upbringing in a family that valued education and service laid the foundation for who I am today. The moment I chose to work directly with people in need instead of pursuing a graduate degree was a defining point in my life, and it wasn't just a decision—it felt like a calling. I'm grateful for the support I received from my family, my pastor, and my mentors, who helped me navigate that time with clarity and confidence. Even now, as I continue my work in social services, I feel deeply connected to my roots and the people who have been a part of my journey. I don't regret the path I've taken, and I'm proud of the life I've built—one that aligns with my values, my purpose, and the love of my family and community.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Leah Robinson: My immediate family includes my two grandparents on my father's side, both of whom I have a close relationship with. My grandfather, who is now in his late 70s, was a community leader in our town and still enjoys mentoring young people, especially those interested in education and service. He's the one who introduced me to the idea that helping others isn't just a job—it's a way of life. My grandmother, on the other hand, is more of a spiritual guide for me. She's been a member of our church for over 50 years and has always emphasized the importance of faith and compassion. She's the one who taught me how to pray with intention and how to listen more than I speak. I also have an uncle who lives in Houston, and while we don't see each other as often as I'd like, he's always been a source of encouragement and support. He's a civil rights advocate, and his work has inspired me to think more critically about the systems we live under. Overall, my family has been a constant source of strength, wisdom, and love, and I'm grateful for each of them in their own unique way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Leah Robinson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been incredibly important to me over the years. One of them is Marcus, a fellow social worker who I met during my first job at the nonprofit. We've been friends for over a decade now, and he's been like a brother to me. He's the one who kept me grounded during some of the toughest times in my career, reminding me why I chose this path in the first place. Then there's Dr. Elena Martinez, my former professor who became a mentor. She's been a constant source of guidance and encouragement, and I still reach out to her whenever I'm facing a challenging case or decision. I also have a close group of friends from church—people who have been there for me through every season of life. They've helped me stay connected to my faith and reminded me of the importance of community. While I don't have a romantic partner right now, I've never felt alone because of the people who surround me. They've shaped my journey just as much as my family has, and I'm deeply grateful for their presence in my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Leah Robinson: I live in a neighborhood in Dallas called Oak Lawn, which is a vibrant and diverse area with a strong sense of community. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a real blend of cultures and backgrounds here. I love that there are plenty of local businesses, from family-owned restaurants to small bookstores and community centers. The park nearby is a favorite spot for me—especially on weekends when I can take a walk or sit and read with my coffee. It's a peaceful place to reflect, and it reminds me of the small towns I grew up in. I also appreciate how accessible public services are here, which is important for my work in social services. There's a lot of activity in the neighborhood too—community events, food festivals, and even volunteer drives that bring people together. I feel like I'm part of something bigger here, and I'm grateful for the warmth and support of the people who live in this area. It's not perfect, of course, but it's a place where I can be myself, do my work, and still feel connected to the values that shaped me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Leah Robinson: I feel very safe in Oak Lawn. It's a neighborhood where people know each other, and there's a sense of mutual respect and care. I've never felt threatened or unwelcome here, which is something I really appreciate. I think it has a lot to do with the community spirit—there's always someone looking out for you, whether it's a neighbor checking in on you after a long day or a local business owner offering a friendly greeting. That sense of safety isn't just about avoiding danger; it's about feeling seen, valued, and supported. It makes a huge difference in my day-to-day life, especially since my work often involves walking through different parts of the city. Knowing that I can return home to a place where I feel at peace is something I'm truly grateful for.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Leah Robinson: Living here in Oak Lawn has been mostly positive, but like any place, it has its challenges. One of the things I appreciate most is the diversity—it's a neighborhood where people from all walks of life come together, and that mirrors the kind of world I want to work in. But sometimes, that diversity can also bring tension, especially when it comes to issues like gentrification or rising housing costs. I've seen some long-time residents struggle to stay in the area as property values go up, and that's something that weighs on me as someone who works in social services. I try to stay involved in local initiatives that support affordable housing and community programs, because I believe in giving back to the place that has given me so much. On the flip side, I love the sense of belonging here, the way people look out for one another, and the opportunities for connection. It's not without its struggles, but overall, I feel like I'm in a place where I can make a difference, both in my work and in my own life.

Going through the recent interview questions about my family and current neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. When talking about my family, I realized how much their support and values have guided me, especially in making the choice to work directly with people in need. Even though I don't have a partner or children, my family remains a constant source of love and strength. My parents, my sister, and my grandparents have all played a role in who I am today, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. As for my neighborhood in Oak Lawn, it feels like home. The sense of community, the diversity, and the safety I experience here are all things I value deeply. It's a place where I can be myself, do meaningful work, and feel connected to the values I was raised with. Even though there are challenges, like rising housing costs and gentrification, I'm committed to being part of the solution and giving back to this community that has given me so much.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Leah Robinson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on the needs of the people I serve. I start most mornings around 6:30 a.m., making sure I have time to pray and get centered before the day begins. I work full-time at a nonprofit that supports at-risk youth and families in crisis, so my days are often filled with meetings, case management, and community outreach. Mondays are usually the busiest, with team meetings and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about direct service—visiting clients, attending support groups, and sometimes even helping with school programs. Thursdays are often a mix of both, with some administrative work and some fieldwork. Fridays are usually a bit lighter, allowing me to catch up on paperwork or attend a community event. I also make it a point to attend church every Sunday, which is a time for reflection, worship, and connecting with my faith community. Evenings are usually spent either catching up with friends, reading, or helping out with a local initiative. While the work can be demanding, I find that the rhythm of my week keeps me grounded and reminds me why I chose this path. It's not always easy, but it's deeply meaningful.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Leah Robinson: I work full-time as a social worker at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on supporting at-risk youth, families in crisis, and individuals dealing with homelessness or mental health challenges. My work hours typically run from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, though I often stay late on days when there are meetings or urgent cases that need attention. I also do some evening work on weekends when needed, especially if there's a community event or outreach program I'm involved in. My role involves a lot of direct client interaction—whether it's conducting home visits, facilitating support groups, or connecting people with resources like housing, food assistance, or healthcare. I also collaborate with other organizations, schools, and local government agencies to ensure that the people we serve have access to the help they need. It's a demanding job, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I get to see the impact of my work in real time, and that keeps me motivated, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Leah Robinson: Outside of my work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I'm an early riser, and I try to wake up before the sun comes up to spend some quiet time in prayer and journaling. It's my way of setting intentions for the day and staying connected to my faith. I also make it a point to cook most of my meals at home, which is something I learned from my mother. She always said that food is love, and I believe that. I enjoy experimenting with different recipes, especially ones that reflect the diverse cultures in my neighborhood. On the weekends, when I'm not working, I like to take long walks in the park or visit local bookstores. Reading has always been a comfort to me, and I find that it helps me process the challenges of my work. I also volunteer a few hours a month with a local youth mentorship program, which is something I'm passionate about. It's not just about giving back—it's about staying connected to the very people I work with every day. These routines, small as they may seem, are what keep me grounded and remind me of the values that have shaped my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Leah Robinson: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started attending a weekly meditation group at my church, and it's been a game-changer for me. It helps me center myself before the day begins, especially with the demands of my job. I also began taking short, guided meditation sessions during my lunch break, which has made a noticeable difference in how I handle stress. Another change is that I've started walking to work a few times a week instead of driving. It's not just about being eco-friendly—it's also a way to clear my mind and stay active. I've noticed that these small shifts have helped me feel more present and grounded, which is something I really need in my line of work. It's amazing how a few intentional habits can make such a big difference in your overall well-being.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Leah Robinson: I don't have children of my own, but I've been a mentor to several young people through the youth program I volunteer with, and I often think about what a typical school day might look like for someone else's child. For example, if I were to imagine a weekday for a child in my community, it might start with waking up early, getting ready for school, and then heading off to a school that serves a diverse population. After school, they might participate in after-school programs like tutoring, sports, or arts, which are essential for keeping kids engaged and safe. I've seen how these programs can make a real difference in a child's life, especially for those from families facing challenges like poverty or instability. While I don't have children of my own, I try to be a positive influence in the lives of the youth I work with, and I often think about what kind of support systems they need to thrive. It's something I'm deeply passionate about, and I believe that every child deserves the chance to grow up in an environment that nurtures their potential.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 has reminded me of how much my life is shaped by the people and places I hold dear. Talking about my family and the values they instilled in me brought back memories of the support I received during my crossroads moment, and how that decision still guides my work today. Reflecting on my neighborhood in Oak Lawn, I feel a deep sense of gratitude for the community that has embraced me and the sense of safety and belonging it provides. My daily routines, from my early morning prayers to my work as a social worker, all tie back to the purpose I've chosen for myself. Even the small changes I've made, like incorporating mindfulness and walking to work, show how I continue to grow and adapt in my journey. It's all connected—my past, my present, and the people who help me navigate it all.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Leah Robinson: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. I've always been pretty active, partly because of my work, which requires a lot of walking and being on my feet. I try to stay as healthy as I can through diet and exercise, but there have been times when stress has taken a toll on me. A few years ago, I went through a period of burnout that left me feeling physically and emotionally drained. I had to take a step back and really focus on self-care—scheduling regular check-ups, eating better, and making sure I was getting enough rest. I also started seeing a therapist, which was something I hadn't done before, but it made a huge difference in how I managed stress and anxiety. I've learned that my mental health is just as important as my physical health, and I make a conscious effort to maintain both. I also try to stay up to date with my vaccinations and regular screenings, especially since I work closely with vulnerable populations. Overall, I feel like I'm in a much better place now, and I'm more aware of how to take care of myself in the long run.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Leah Robinson: For me, staying healthy is both easier and harder in different ways. On one hand, my work keeps me active—whether it's walking through neighborhoods, visiting clients, or attending community events. I also have a strong support system that reminds me to take care of myself, whether it's my pastor checking in on me or my friends encouraging me to take a break when I need to. But on the other hand, the emotional weight of my job can make it hard to stay balanced. There are days when I come home exhausted, not just physically but emotionally, and it's easy to skip meals or push through fatigue instead of resting. I've learned that I have to be intentional about self-care, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed. It's not always easy, but I've come to see it as a non-negotiable part of my work and my well-being. I try to remind myself that I can't pour from an empty cup, and that staying healthy isn't just about me—it's about being able to show up for the people I serve with my full heart and energy.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Leah Robinson: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that I didn't realize was as severe as it was. It started as a mild discomfort after long days at work, but over time, it became more persistent, especially after long hours of walking or sitting at my desk. I finally went to see a doctor, and it turned out to be a combination of muscle strain and early signs of degenerative disc disease. It was a wake-up call for me to take my physical health more seriously. I started seeing a physical therapist, and I've been incorporating more stretching and strengthening exercises into my routine. I also had to adjust my work habits a bit—like using a standing desk and taking more frequent breaks to move around. It's been a process, but I'm grateful I addressed it before it got worse. It's reminded me that even though I'm used to pushing through, my body has limits, and I need to listen to it more. It's also made me more empathetic toward the people I work with, especially those who deal with chronic pain or mobility issues. I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy—it's about being present for the people who need me most.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Leah Robinson: The back pain has definitely had an impact on my work, especially during the days when I'm on my feet for long stretches or traveling between different locations. I've had to be more mindful of how I move and sit, and I've had to adjust some of my routines to accommodate my body's needs. There were a few weeks where I was struggling to keep up with the demands of my job, and I had to take a short leave to focus on my recovery. It was humbling, but it also taught me the importance of pacing myself and not pushing through pain just because I feel like I should. I've learned to ask for help when I need it—whether it's delegating tasks at work or leaning on my friends and family for support. It's not easy to admit that I need to slow down, but I've come to see it as a form of strength. I'm still able to work, but I do it with more awareness and care now. It's also made me more compassionate toward the people I serve, especially those who are dealing with health challenges that limit their ability to work or care for their families. I want them to know that it's okay to ask for help, and that healing is a process—not something that happens overnight.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Leah Robinson: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel incredibly grateful for the work I'm doing and the people I'm surrounded by, and other days I feel the weight of the challenges we're facing as a community. The pandemic has had a lasting impact, even though things have started to feel more normalized now. I've seen a lot of people struggling with mental health, housing insecurity, and access to basic needs, which has been both heartbreaking and motivating. I've also been working more closely with local organizations to address these issues, which has given me a renewed sense of purpose. On a personal level, I've been trying to focus more on self-compassion and balance, especially after dealing with my back pain. I've found solace in my faith, my friendships, and the small moments of joy—like watching the sunset from my porch or sharing a meal with my family. It's been a year of growth, resilience, and learning to lean on the support systems that have always been there for me.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 has made me reflect on how my health and well-being are deeply intertwined with the demands of my work and the support systems I have in place. It's easy to push through exhaustion or physical discomfort when I'm focused on helping others, but I've come to realize that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. The mindfulness practices I've incorporated into my routine, like meditation and walking to work, have helped me stay grounded and present, even on the hardest days. At the same time, I've learned that my chronic back pain is a reminder that my body has limits, and I need to listen to it. It's also made me more empathetic toward the people I serve, especially those who are dealing with their own health challenges. I've grown to see self-care not just as something I do for myself, but as a way to show up for others with more energy, compassion, and clarity. It's a journey I'm still on, but I'm grateful for the lessons it's teaching me.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Leah Robinson: I've definitely struggled with anxiety at times, especially during the busiest periods of my work or when I'm juggling multiple responsibilities. There were moments when the weight of everything—my job, my health, and the needs of the people I serve—felt overwhelming. I remember one particularly stressful time when I was working late nights and feeling like I wasn't doing enough for the people I wanted to help. I started experiencing panic attacks, which was new for me, and it scared me. I didn't want to admit that I was struggling because I felt like I should be stronger, more resilient. But eventually, I realized that asking for help wasn't a sign of weakness—it was a sign of courage. I started seeing a therapist, and that made a world of difference. Through therapy, I learned how to recognize the signs of anxiety and how to manage it with tools like deep breathing, journaling, and setting boundaries. I also leaned on my faith and my community, which reminded me that I wasn't alone in this. I've come to see anxiety not as something to be ashamed of, but as a part of the human experience—one that I can learn to live with, not be controlled by. It's still something I have to be mindful of, but I'm much more equipped to handle it now, and that's given me a greater sense of peace in my life.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Leah Robinson: My family has been incredibly supportive throughout this past year, especially as I've navigated my health challenges and the emotional toll of my work. My parents have been there for me every step of the way, offering both practical help and emotional support. My father, in particular, has been a steady presence, reminding me that it's okay to slow down and take care of myself. My mother, though she's always been busy with her job, makes sure to check in on me regularly and even cooks for me when I'm having a tough week. My sister has also been a great source of encouragement—she's the one who reminded me to take time for myself and not lose sight of my own well-being. As for my grandparents, they've been a spiritual anchor for me. My grandmother especially has been praying for me and reminding me that God is with me through every challenge. I feel deeply blessed to have such a strong, loving family who lifts me up when I'm struggling. They've helped me remember that I'm not alone in this, and that's something I'm truly grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Leah Robinson: For me, religion and spirituality are the foundation of who I am. Growing up in a Protestant household, I was taught that faith was not just something you practiced on Sundays—it was a way of life, a lens through which I saw the world and my place in it. My grandmother, in particular, instilled in me the belief that prayer was a conversation, not just a ritual. She would often say, 'God doesn't need your words, but He wants your heart.' That has stayed with me through every season of life. My faith has been my anchor, especially during the hardest times—whether it was deciding my career path, dealing with my back pain, or feeling the weight of the world in my work. It's what gives me the strength to keep going, to believe that even in the darkest moments, there is light. I also find comfort in the community of my church, where I'm surrounded by people who share my values and support one another. Spirituality isn't just about believing in something bigger than myself—it's about living with purpose, compassion, and gratitude. It's how I make sense of the chaos and find meaning in the everyday.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Leah Robinson: I actually don't use social media very often, and when I do, it's more for staying in touch with family and friends rather than for scrolling through news or trends. I have a Facebook account where I keep up with my parents, my sister, and some of my cousins, especially since we don't all live in the same area. I also follow a few community groups that post about local events or initiatives related to social services, which helps me stay connected to what's happening in my neighborhood. I've never really been drawn to platforms like Instagram or Twitter, partly because I find them overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I prefer more meaningful, one-on-one connections over the fast-paced, often superficial nature of social media. That said, I do think there's value in using these platforms to raise awareness about important issues—like housing insecurity or mental health support—which is why I occasionally share articles or event information from my nonprofit's page. For me, it's about using technology as a tool for connection and purpose, not distraction.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Leah Robinson: Honestly, I haven't relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think my support system has always been more personal and grounded—my family, my faith community, and the people I work with. When I'm going through something difficult, I tend to reach out to my mom or my pastor first, or maybe sit with my friends at church and just talk it through. There's something about face-to-face connection or even a phone call that feels more real and comforting than scrolling through a screen. That said, I do appreciate when people in my community use social media to raise awareness or organize support for causes we care about. I've seen some amazing initiatives come out of local groups, and I think that's a positive use of these platforms. For me personally, though, I've always found strength in the people I know and love, not in the virtual world.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 has made me reflect deeply on how my health and mental well-being are intertwined with the demands of my work and the support systems I have in place. Dealing with chronic back pain has been a humbling experience, reminding me that my body has limits and that I need to listen to it more closely. It's not easy to slow down, especially when I feel like I should be doing more for others, but I've come to see that taking care of myself is not a weakness—it's a necessity. The emotional weight of my job, combined with the physical challenges I've faced, has also brought anxiety into my life in new ways. I used to think I could push through everything, but I've learned that asking for help is a form of strength. Through therapy, faith, and the support of my family and friends, I've found tools to manage my anxiety and stay grounded. It's a journey I'm still on, but I'm grateful for the lessons it's teaching me about self-compassion, resilience, and the importance of community.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Leah Robinson: Over the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have fluctuated, but I've been more intentional about how I manage it. There were times when the weight of my work felt heavier, especially with the ongoing challenges in our community and the personal struggles with my back pain. But I've also found new ways to cope—like the mindfulness practices I've started incorporating into my routine. I've been journaling more, which helps me process my emotions and clarify my thoughts. I also find that my faith has been a constant source of comfort. On days when I feel overwhelmed, I take time to pray or read scripture, which reminds me of my purpose and gives me a sense of peace. I've also leaned more on my support system—whether it's my friends from church, my family, or even my coworkers. We've started having more open conversations about mental health, which has been really healing. I think the biggest change for me has been learning to accept that it's okay to not be okay, and that healing is a process. I'm still learning, but I feel more equipped to handle stress and worry now than I did before.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Leah Robinson: My biggest expenses last month were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a two-bedroom apartment in Oak Lawn, and the rent is around $1,500 a month. I try to keep it manageable by staying in a smaller space and not upgrading to anything too fancy. Groceries are another big one—since I cook most of my meals at home, I try to buy in bulk and stick to seasonal produce, but with the rising prices, it's still a significant chunk of my budget. I also have a car, which I use for work and errands, and the monthly payment, insurance, and gas add up to about $400. I also set aside money for my health insurance, which is important because of my back pain and the need for regular physical therapy. I try to budget carefully, and I also take advantage of community resources like food pantries and free health clinics when needed. I don't have a lot of debt, and I'm pretty disciplined about saving, even if it's just a little each month. It's not always easy, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most—my health, my work, and my family.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Leah Robinson: My household spending last month was around $2,800, which is pretty close to what I usually spend each month. The majority of that goes toward rent, groceries, and transportation, as I mentioned earlier. I also set aside about $300 for utilities, which includes electricity, water, and internet. I try to keep my expenses as predictable as possible, which helps me manage my budget better. I also allocate a small portion of my income for personal care items, books, and occasional outings with friends or church events. While I don't have a lot of discretionary income, I find that prioritizing essentials like health and community connections helps me feel more grounded and secure. I've also started using budgeting apps to track my spending, which has been helpful in identifying areas where I can cut back or save more. Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with how I'm managing my finances, especially considering my work in social services, where I often see people struggling with much less than I have.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Leah Robinson: We rent our home. I live in a two-bedroom apartment in Oak Lawn, which I chose because it's close to my work and the community feels welcoming. Renting has been the practical choice for me, especially given the rising costs of homeownership in this area. I've considered buying a home in the future, but for now, renting allows me more flexibility, especially with my career and the possibility of needing to move for new opportunities or community projects. I also like the idea of being able to invest in my own growth and savings rather than tying up money in property. It's not without its challenges, especially with the ongoing issues of gentrification and rising rents, but I've found ways to make it work—like staying in a smaller space and being mindful of my budget. I'm grateful for the stability I have, and I know that for many people in my community, renting is the only realistic option. It's something I think about often, especially as I see more of my neighbors struggling to keep their homes.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Leah Robinson: Over the past year, my bills have had some noticeable fluctuations, especially with the seasons and the ongoing costs of living in Dallas. For example, during the summer months, my electricity bill tends to go up because of the heat, and I end up using more air conditioning. I also noticed that my internet and phone bills stayed pretty consistent, but I did have to pay a bit more for a new phone last spring, which was an unexpected expense. Then there were the holidays—around Thanksgiving and Christmas, I spent a little more on groceries and small gifts for family and friends, which added up. I also had to pay for a few unexpected things, like a new pair of shoes for work and a few extra sessions with my physical therapist after I had a flare-up of my back pain. On the other hand, some months were quieter financially, like during the winter when I didn't have to spend as much on cooling or outdoor activities. I've learned to budget a little extra each month for these kinds of fluctuations, and I try to use community resources when possible to ease the burden. It's not always easy, but I've gotten better at planning ahead and staying flexible with my finances.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 has reminded me of how deeply my family and faith have supported me during my health struggles and emotional challenges. It's easy to feel isolated when dealing with anxiety or chronic pain, but knowing that my family is always there—whether it's my parents offering practical help, my sister reminding me to take care of myself, or my grandmother praying for me—has been a source of strength. I've also come to appreciate that while I don't rely on social media for emotional support, I do see its value in raising awareness and connecting people to important causes. It's comforting to know that I have a strong, grounded support system that helps me navigate life's difficulties without needing to turn to virtual spaces for validation or help.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Leah Robinson: I do have a savings account, and I try to save a little bit each month, even if it's just a small amount. It's not always easy, especially with the way my income can fluctuate depending on the workload at the nonprofit, but I've made it a habit. I set up automatic transfers right after I get paid, so it feels less like a choice and more like a commitment to myself. I also keep a separate emergency fund for unexpected expenses, like the physical therapy sessions or the new phone I had to buy last year. It's not a lot, maybe around $500, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I have something to fall back on. I think saving is important because it's a way of taking care of myself and my future, especially when I see so many people in my community struggling to make ends meet. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I believe that even small steps toward financial security can make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Leah Robinson: For me, saving has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected, especially given the nature of my work and the challenges I've faced with my health. Last year, I focused on building up my emergency fund a bit more, knowing that things can change quickly—whether it's a sudden medical expense, a car repair, or a period where my income might dip due to workload or personal circumstances. I also set aside a small amount each month for future goals, like maybe one day being able to take a short trip or invest in further education if the opportunity arises. But honestly, the majority of my savings have been about security—knowing that I have a little cushion to fall back on if something comes up. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to give me peace of mind and remind me that I'm not just living paycheck to paycheck. I think that's especially important for someone in my line of work, where the needs of others can sometimes take precedence over my own financial planning. Still, I try to balance that with being responsible and forward-thinking.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Leah Robinson: My occupation is as a social worker, specifically at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' where I focus on supporting at-risk youth, families in crisis, and individuals dealing with homelessness or mental health challenges. The most important activities in my role involve direct client interaction—whether it's conducting home visits, facilitating support groups, or connecting people with resources like housing, food assistance, or healthcare. I also collaborate with other organizations, schools, and local government agencies to ensure that the people we serve have access to the help they need. One of the most meaningful parts of my job is being able to build trust with the people I work with. It's not just about providing services; it's about listening, understanding their stories, and walking alongside them through their struggles. I've had the privilege of seeing people transform their lives, and that's what keeps me motivated, even on the hardest days. I believe in the power of community and compassion, and I'm honored to be part of something that makes a real difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Leah Robinson: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the needs of the people I serve. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up meetings or prepare for the next day's appointments. I also do some evening work on weekends, especially when there are community events or outreach programs I'm involved in. My job is demanding, but I've learned to manage my time carefully, especially since I've been dealing with my back pain. I make sure to take breaks throughout the day, stretch when I can, and sometimes even leave early if I need to rest. It's not always easy balancing work with self-care, but I've come to see that it's necessary for both my well-being and the people I serve. I'm grateful for the flexibility my job allows, even if it means working long hours at times.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Leah Robinson: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. My work at 'Community Roots' has been my primary focus for the past several years, and I've found that the demands of social work require a lot of dedication and presence. I do take on some additional responsibilities, like volunteering with the youth mentorship program a few hours a month, but that's more of a passion project than a second job. I've considered part-time work in the past, especially when I was still in school, but once I committed to this path, I wanted to give it my full attention. There's a lot that goes into this work—building relationships, understanding people's needs, and being there for them when they need it most. I don't think I could do it justice if I was splitting my time too much. That said, I'm always open to learning new skills or taking on short-term projects that align with my values and the needs of my community. It's about balance, and I've learned to be intentional about how I spend my time and energy.

I've come to see that it's okay to not be okay, and that healing is a process—not something that happens overnight. At the same time, navigating my monthly budget and the fluctuations in my expenses has reminded me of the importance of financial planning and the value of community resources. I'm grateful for the small but meaningful ways I've been able to take care of myself, both emotionally and financially, and I'm learning to balance the demands of my work with the need to prioritize my own well-being. It's a journey, but I feel more equipped to handle life's challenges now than I did before.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Leah Robinson: My household income last month was around $3,200. That comes from my full-time job at the nonprofit, which pays a steady salary, and I also received a small stipend from a local grant program that supports community workers with chronic health conditions. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my basic needs and give me some flexibility. I try to be careful with my money, especially since I know how many people in my community are struggling with far less than I have. I also take advantage of any opportunities for professional development or community grants that can help me grow in my work or provide additional support. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I'm grateful for the stability I have and the fact that I can contribute to my community while still taking care of myself.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Leah Robinson: I've been at 'Community Roots' for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth, both personally and professionally. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is one of the most important, especially since I've been dealing with my back pain and need regular physical therapy. We also get a certain number of paid days off, including vacation and sick time, which is something I've come to appreciate more as I've learned to prioritize my well-being. There's also some professional development support, like funding for workshops or conferences, which helps me stay connected to the latest practices in social work. While the salary isn't high, the work is deeply meaningful, and the people I work with are incredibly dedicated. I feel like I'm part of a team that genuinely cares about the community we serve, and that makes all the difference. It's not always easy, but I know I'm making an impact, and that gives me a sense of purpose that I can't put a price on.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Leah Robinson: My relationships at work are pretty much like family. I've been at 'Community Roots' for six years, and over time, I've developed deep connections with my coworkers. We're all in this together, supporting each other through the ups and downs of the job. My manager, Ms. Thompson, is someone I really respect—she's not just a leader, but a mentor. She's always been there to listen, offer guidance, and remind us why we do what we do. She understands the emotional weight of this work, and she leads with compassion, which sets the tone for the whole team. As for my coworkers, we've built a strong sense of camaraderie. We share the same values, and we're all driven by the desire to make a difference. There are days when the work is overwhelming, but knowing that I have a team of people who genuinely care about each other and the community we serve makes it all worth it. I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Leah Robinson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually start at 8:00 a.m. and finish at 5:00 p.m., but depending on the needs of the people we serve, I might stay a little later or come in a bit earlier. For example, if there's a case that requires more attention or if we're preparing for a community event, I'll adjust my hours accordingly. That flexibility is important because it allows me to be present for the people I work with, even if it means staying late or coming in early. At the same time, I've learned to set boundaries for myself, especially since I've been dealing with my back pain. I make sure to take breaks when I need to, and I'm not afraid to leave early if I feel overwhelmed. It's a balance, but one that works for me. I think the predictability of the schedule helps me manage my time better, especially with my personal responsibilities and self-care routines. Overall, I feel like I have a good amount of control over my work hours, which is something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Leah Robinson: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, even though it's not extravagant. I know that I'm in a better position than many people in my community, and I try to use that as a reminder to be grateful and responsible with what I have. I've learned to live within my means, prioritize what truly matters, and not get caught up in the idea that more is always better. I also feel a deep sense of purpose in my work, which gives me a kind of fulfillment that money can't buy. There are definitely days when I worry about the future or when unexpected expenses come up, but I've built a routine that helps me stay grounded. I've also learned to lean on my community and the resources available to me, whether it's through food pantries, free clinics, or local support groups. I don't see my financial situation as a limitation, but rather as a foundation that allows me to do the work I love and support the people I care about. I know there's always room to grow, but right now, I feel like I'm in a good place.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Leah Robinson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a professor at a local university, and my mother was a nurse. They both worked full-time, and their careers were a big part of our family life. My father would often come home after his classes and sit down with me to talk about what he was teaching, which sparked my love for learning. My mother, on the other hand, was always on her feet, working long hours at the hospital, but she always made time for us. She taught me the importance of compassion and service, which has stayed with me throughout my life. Their dedication to their work not only provided for our family but also set an example for me about the value of education, hard work, and giving back to the community. I feel so grateful for the sacrifices they made, and I think their work ethic and values are what shaped the person I am today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Leah Robinson: My father was a professor of sociology at a local university, and his work focused on community development and social justice. His most important activities involved teaching, conducting research, and advising students who were interested in making a difference in their communities. He often hosted discussions in his home, where students and community members would gather to talk about issues like education reform, poverty, and racial equity. He believed that knowledge was a tool for empowerment, and he always encouraged me to ask questions and think critically about the world around me. My mother, on the other hand, was a nurse at a community health clinic, and her most important duties involved providing care to underserved populations. She was especially passionate about working with low-income families and people of color, who often faced systemic barriers to healthcare. She taught me the value of compassion, the importance of listening, and the power of showing up for people in their most vulnerable moments. Both of their jobs were more than just careers—they were callings, and I think that's what inspired me to choose a path that also serves others.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Leah Robinson: My father worked at a public university in our town, and my mother was employed at a community health clinic that served a lot of low-income families. Both of their workplaces were more than just places of employment—they were spaces where they could make a real difference in people's lives. My father's university was a place of learning and growth, and he had a lot of influence in shaping the curriculum around social justice and community engagement. He often brought students into our home for discussions or meals, which made me feel like I was part of something bigger. My mother's clinic was a small, family-run facility that provided essential healthcare services to people who might not have had access otherwise. She worked long hours, but she always made time to care for her patients with kindness and patience. I remember seeing her come home exhausted but still full of compassion, and that taught me the value of service and dedication. Their work wasn't just about earning a paycheck—it was about building a better world, one person at a time.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Leah Robinson: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to still be in this work, but maybe with a little more balance and a few more tools in my toolbox. I want to continue supporting at-risk youth and families in crisis, but I also hope to have the opportunity to mentor more young people, especially those who are considering careers in social work or community service. I see so much potential in the next generation, and I want to be a part of guiding them toward paths that are meaningful and sustainable. I also hope to have a stronger presence in my neighborhood—maybe even start a small initiative that brings people together around shared goals, like affordable housing or mental health awareness. On a personal level, I hope to continue growing in my faith, deepening my relationships with my family, and taking better care of my body so I can keep showing up for the people I love and serve. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to keep walking this path with purpose, compassion, and hope.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Leah Robinson: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection to my family, my community, and the people I serve. I believe that relationships are the foundation of everything else, and I've seen how they can heal, support, and transform lives. My faith is also something I hold dear; it's not just a belief system for me, but a way of living with purpose and gratitude. I value the work I do because it allows me to be part of something bigger than myself, to walk alongside people in their struggles and celebrate their victories. I also value growth—both personal and collective. I believe we all have the capacity to change, to learn, and to become better versions of ourselves. And finally, I value balance. Life is full of challenges, but I've learned that it's the small, intentional moments—the laughter with friends, the quiet time with my family, the peace I find in prayer—that give me the strength to keep going. These things, more than anything else, are what I carry with me every day.
